issue.title: "No such file or directory"
issue.body:
Hi everyone, I was trying to build simbody from the source code for OpenSim purpose. I followed every step from the Github page and it seems working fine. However, as I would test the pendulum code in the visual studio this error always pops out. I have searched for solution (inlclude/lib, etc.) and they cant' seem work.

![vscode_error](https://github.com/simbody/simbody/assets/115923671/90df0cb4-b197-4271-9051-4801818b1b23)

I am very keen to make this work, therefore I tried to create a solution file in visual studio and it worked! My question is, does this mean that I cannot use Simbody with vscode? Or did I miss any important steps?
Thank you for your help

comment.body:
While I do not develop on vscode, it looks like there's a plugin to use CMake in vscode https://devblogs.microsoft.com/cppblog/cmake-tools-extension-for-visual-studio-code/
This is more a question to the CMake/vscode community rather than simbody but let us know hwat you fins out as would like to document the steps since more users are likely to use vscode moving forward. Thank you

issue.title: "No such file or directory"
issue.body:
Hi everyone, I was trying to build simbody from the source code for OpenSim purpose. I followed every step from the Github page and it seems working fine. However, as I would test the pendulum code in the visual studio this error always pops out. I have searched for solution (inlclude/lib, etc.) and they cant' seem work.

![vscode_error](https://github.com/simbody/simbody/assets/115923671/90df0cb4-b197-4271-9051-4801818b1b23)

I am very keen to make this work, therefore I tried to create a solution file in visual studio and it worked! My question is, does this mean that I cannot use Simbody with vscode? Or did I miss any important steps?
Thank you for your help

comment.body:
Hi, could anybody help me out to solve this problem? I have tried different ways to find out the problem with this "No such file or directory" issue? I have tried to build and install with CMake and also installing from conda-forge, this issue always pops out. Is it not possible to use simbody with visual studio code? 
I appreciate your help
typo correction:  "... that this string (i.e., ```nullStr```) will NOT be the source of a leak."

commits.message:
Added access to State indices for ExponentialSpringForce (#763)

* Added access to State indices for ExponentialSpringForce

Class ExponentialSpringForce has 4 states:
- Static coefficient of friction (discrete)
- Kinetic coefficient of friction (discrete)
- Sliding state (auto-update discrete)
- Elastic anchor point (auto-update discrete)

A typical user will not need the State indices of these states.

Access to the indices is provided so that other modeling frameworks written on top of Simbody, such as OpenSim, can get the values of a States in a generic way.  Specifically, with the indices, the values can be obtained by calling

SimTK::Subsystem::getDiscreteVariable(const State& s, DiscreteVariableIndex index)

A few trailing white spaces were also removed.

* Testing index accessors for exponential springs

The unit tests in TestExponentialSpring.cpp now include tests for
- getMuStaticStateIndex()
- getMuKineticStateIndex()
- getSlidingStateIndex()
- getAnchorPointStateIndex()

* Shortened documentation for state index accessors.

* Revamped documentation for state index accessors.

All state index accessors are now located at the end of ExponentialSpringForce.h and are collected under a Doxygen group named "State Indices (Advanced)". As a result, some repetition has been eliminated, and the clarity of the documentation improved.

---------

Co-authored-by: Clay Anderson <fcanderson@users.noreply.github.com>

pull_request.title: Added access to State indices for ExponentialSpringForce
pull_request.body: Class ExponentialSpringForce has 4 states: - Static coefficient of friction (discrete) - Kinetic coefficient of friction (discrete) - Sliding state (auto-update discrete) - Elastic anchor point (auto-update discrete) A 'get' method for the State index of each of the above states has been added: - ```ExponentialSpringForce::getMuStaticStateIndex()``` - ```ExponentialSpringForce::getMuKineticStateIndex()``` - ```ExponentialSpringForce::getSlidingStateIndex()``` - ```ExponentialSpringForce::getAnchorPointStateIndex()``` A typical user will not need to call these methods. Access to the indices is provided so that modeling frameworks written on top of Simbody, such as OpenSim, can get the values of the states in a generic way. For example, a discrete state value can be obtained by calling the following method if its state index is know: ``` SimTK::Subsystem::getDiscreteVariable(const State& s, DiscreteVariableIndex index) ``` Tests for these methods have been added to the unit test for class ExponentialSpringForce (see TestExponentialSpring.cpp). Documentation for these new methods has also been added. A few trailing white spaces were also removed. - - - This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/simbody/simbody/763)

review.body: very nice! BTW I learned recently that "indexes" is an [acceptable alternative](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/index) to "indices". In a programming context I found I sometimes like it better because I have variables like BodyIndex for which it seems better in comments to say BodyIndexes leaving the variable name unchanged. There is also a small advantage when searching or renaming because searching for "BodyIndex" matches "BodyIndexes" but not "BodyIndices". > Reviewed 1 of 1 files at r2, all commit messages. > *[Reviewable](https://reviewable.io/reviews/simbody/simbody/763#-:-NesQ3FE947lRpTqqJF8:b-a2azcr)* status: :shipit: complete! all files reviewed, all discussions resolved (waiting on @fcanderson)

comment.body: Thanks for the comments, Sherm.  I'll explore the @name group to unify the documentation and correct the typo you found.

review.body:
Looks good -- I have a suggestion for reorganizing the documentation to eliminate duplication, PTAL.

> Reviewed 3 of 3 files at r1, all commit messages.
> *[Reviewable](https://reviewable.io/reviews/simbody/simbody/763#-:-NeFsAfuCo0Wz6H8GWhM:b-awabq9)* status: all files reviewed, 2 unresolved discussions (waiting on @fcanderson)

___
*[`Simbody/include/simbody/internal/ExponentialSpringForce.h` line 408 at r1](https://reviewable.io/reviews/simbody/simbody/763#-NeFpGbq7r1eGvx1djBF:-NeFpGbq7r1eGvx1djBG:b2cvp1p) ([raw file](https://github.com/simbody/simbody/blob/99a7a8efbb1387d274a5476dbdc162a73612369c/Simbody/include/simbody/internal/ExponentialSpringForce.h#L408)):*
> ```objc
>     const ExponentialSpringParameters& getParameters() const;
> 
>     /** Get the State index of the static coefficient of friction (μₛ) for
> ```

BTW consider moving these more-obscure expert user functions to the end of the list rather than having them show up in the middle with the commonly-used functions. Also, consider beginning each comment with "(Advanced)", e.g.
`/** (Advanced) Get the State index ...`

That will help ordinary users know not to bother looking at these.

As an alternative (probably better) you could use an `@name` grouping to collect all of these index-access methods so they appear together in Doxygen and share common documentation rather than repeating the same text for each function.
___
*[`Simbody/include/simbody/internal/ExponentialSpringForce.h` line 430 at r1](https://reviewable.io/reviews/simbody/simbody/763#-NeFpv8A4nykpnoOlxBT:-NeFpv8A4nykpnoOlxBU:bgo2228) ([raw file](https://github.com/simbody/simbody/blob/99a7a8efbb1387d274a5476dbdc162a73612369c/Simbody/include/simbody/internal/ExponentialSpringForce.h#L430)):*
> ```objc
>     Real getMuStatic(const State& state) const;
> 
>     /** Get the State index assinged to the kinetic coefficient of friction
> ```

typo: assinged (same typo several places below)

Also, consider using the same wording style for similar functions to avoid implying that there is something different here. In the style of the MuStatic method, this would begin "Get the State index of the kinetic ..." (or use "assigned to" in both places)

Better, avoid duplication altogether using `@name` group


<!-- Sent from Reviewable.io -->

issue.title: "No such file or directory"
issue.body:
Hi everyone, I was trying to build simbody from the source code for OpenSim purpose. I followed every step from the Github page and it seems working fine. However, as I would test the pendulum code in the visual studio this error always pops out. I have searched for solution (inlclude/lib, etc.) and they cant' seem work.

![vscode_error](https://github.com/simbody/simbody/assets/115923671/90df0cb4-b197-4271-9051-4801818b1b23)

I am very keen to make this work, therefore I tried to create a solution file in visual studio and it worked! My question is, does this mean that I cannot use Simbody with vscode? Or did I miss any important steps?
Thank you for your help

comment.body: Unfortunately I'm not a vscode user so I don't know the magic incantation. Maybe someone else here can advise?

Thank you for your help

issue.title: "No such file or directory"

Hi everyone, I was trying to build simbody from the source code for OpenSim purpose. I followed every step from the Github page and it seems working fine. However, as I would test the pendulum code in the visual studio this error always pops out. I have searched for solution (inlclude/lib, etc.) and they cant' seem work.

![vscode_error](https://github.com/simbody/simbody/assets/115923671/90df0cb4-b197-4271-9051-4801818b1b23)

I am very keen to make this work, therefore I tried to create a solution file in visual studio and it worked! My question is, does this mean that I cannot use Simbody with vscode? Or did I miss any important steps?
Thank you for your help

pull_request.title: Added access to State indices for ExponentialSpringForce
pull_request.body:
Class ExponentialSpringForce has 4 states:
- Static coefficient of friction (discrete)
- Kinetic coefficient of friction (discrete)
- Sliding state (auto-update discrete)
- Elastic anchor point (auto-update discrete)

Get methods for the state index of each of these states is provided by 4 methods, respectively:
- ```getMuStaticStateIndex()```
- ```getMuKineticStateIndex()```
- ```getSlidingStateIndex()```
- ```getAnchorPointStateIndex()```

A typical user will not need to call these methods.

Access to the indices is provided so that modeling frameworks written on top of Simbody, such as OpenSim, can get the values of states in a generic way.  For example, a discrete state value can be obtained by calling the following method if the corresponding state index is available: 
```
SimTK::Subsystem::getDiscreteVariable(const State& s, DiscreteVariableIndex index)
```
Tests for these methods have been added to the unit test for class ExponentialSpringForce (see TestExponentialSpring.cpp). Documentation for these new methods has also been added.

A few trailing white spaces were also removed.

repo.name: simbody
repo.description: High-performance C++ multibody dynamics/physics library for simulating articulated biomechanical and mechanical systems like vehicles, robots, and the human skeleton.

commits.message:
Precision set to LosslessNumDigitsReal in SimTK::String::String(const T&) (#762)

Precision set to LosslessNumDigitsReal in String::String(T)

To achieve lossless conversion, the ostringstream precision in SimTK::String::String(const T&) is now set to a value of SimTK::LosslessNumDigitsReal, which is typically 20. Documentation is updated.

This change affects SimTK::Xml::setValueAs<T>(const T& value). Now, XML elements representing doubles will have ~20 significant digits instead of ~6, rendering class SimTK::Xml a viable framework for lossless serialization.

---------

Co-authored-by: Clay Anderson <fcanderson@users.noreply.github.com>
